definition:
A magic square of order $n$ is an $n\times n$ array using each one of
the numbers $1,2,3,\ldots,n^2$ once and such that the sum of the numbers
in each row, column or main diagonal is the same.

Example: $$\begin{pmatrix}
8 & 1 & 6\\
3 & 5 & 7\\
4 & 9  & 2
\end{pmatrix}$$

It’s easy to prove that the sum is always $\frac{1}{2}n(n^2+1)$. So in
the example with $n=3$ the sum is always $\frac{1}{2}(3\times 10)=15$.

One way to generalize this concept is to allow any numbers in the
entries, instead of $1,2,\ldots,n$.
